title: Case Study: Progressive Muscle Weakness and Atrophy in Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
clinical_history: A 35-year-old male, Mr. Thompson, presented with a 5-year history of progressive muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower extremities. He reported difficulty walking and frequent tripping over his own feet. He also experienced numbness and tingling sensations in his feet and hands. The patient's symptoms began in his teenage years, with initial complaints of high arches and hammertoes. Over time, his condition progressed, and he developed significant weakness in his ankle and foot muscles, leading to difficulties with ambulation.
aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or running; activities that require balance and coordination
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient shows significant atrophy in the lower extremity muscles, particularly in the calves and thighs.
past_history: The patient has a family history of Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease, with several relatives affected. He has undergone multiple surgeries to correct foot deformities and has been using orthotics for several years.
medical_history: The patient has been diagnosed with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease type 1A, confirmed through genetic testing and electromyography (EMG).
medications: The patient is currently taking gabapentin for neuropathic pain management and vitamin B12 supplements.
personal_history: The patient is married with two children and works as an accountant. He has had to adapt his work environment to accommodate his physical limitations.
imaging: MRI and X-rays of the feet and ankles show significant muscle atrophy and bone deformities, consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease.
